entry.et: Middle English, from Old English tabule & Anglo-French table; both from Latin tabula board, tablet, list

def.dt: :tablet 1a
:backgammon
:one of the two leaves of a backgammon board or either half of a leaf
:a piece of furniture consisting of a smooth flat slab fixed on legs
:a supply or source of food
:an act or instance of assembling to eat :meal sit down to table
:a group of people assembled at or as if at a table
:a legislative or negotiating session the bargaining table
:stringcourse
:a systematic arrangement of data usually in rows and columns for ready reference
:a condensed enumeration :list a table of contents
:something that resembles a table especially in having a plane surface: as
:the upper flat surface of a cut precious stone see brilliant illustration
:tableland
:a horizontal stratum
:up for consideration or negotiation the subject is not on the table
:into a stupor can drink you under the table
:in a covert manner took money under the table
:to enter in a table
:to place on the agenda
:to remove (as a parliamentary motion) from consideration indefinitely
:to put on a table
:suitable for a table or for use at a table a table lamp
:suitable for serving at a table table grapes
:proper for conduct at a table table manners
:a meal served to all guests at a stated hour and fixed price
:a complete meal of several courses offered at a fixed price
:to move from table to table (as in a restaurant) in order to chat with friends
:linen (as tablecloths and napkins) for the table
:a table listing the number and duties of personnel and the major items of equipment authorized for a military unit
:salt suitable for use at the table and in cooking
:foosball
:sugar 1a
:granulated white sugar
